Shown below are rows 1, 2, and 3 of Pascal's triangle.

\[
\begin{array}{ccccccc}
& & 1 & & 1 & & \\
& 1 & & 2 & & 1 & \\
1 & & 3 & & 3 & & 1
\end{array}
\]Let $(a_i),$ $(b_i),$ $(c_i)$ be the sequence, from left to right, of elements in the 2005th, 2006th, and 2007th rows, respectively, with the leftmost element occurring at $i = 0.$  Compute
\[\sum_{i = 0}^{2006} \frac{b_i}{c_i} - \sum_{i = 0}^{2005} \frac{a_i}{b_i}.\]
inference:
The kth term in the nth row of Pascal's triangle is given by ${_{n -1}}C_{k -1}.$  Therefore, the 2005th, 2006th, and 2007th rows of Pascal's triangle are
\[\begin{array}{ccccccccccccccccccc}
& \cdots & 1 & 2004 & {2004 \choose 2} & {2004 \choose 3} & \cdots & {2004 \choose 2003} & {2004 \choose 2004} & \cdots & \\
& \cdots & 1 & 2005 & {2005 \choose 2} & {2005 \choose 3} & \cdots & {2005 \choose 2004} & {2005 \choose 2005} & \cdots & \\
& \cdots & 1 & 2006 & {2006 \choose 2} & {2006 \choose 3} & \cdots & {2006 \choose 2005} & {2006 \choose 2006} & \cdots & \\
\end{array}\]
Since
\[\frac{1}{2} \cdot {2005 \choose 2} = \frac{1}{2} \cdot {2006 \choose 3} = \cdots = \frac{1}{n} \cdot {200n \choose n+1},\]
we have
$$\begin{split} \sum_{i = 0}^{2006} \frac{b_i}{c_i} - \sum_{i = 0}^{2005} \frac{a_i}{b_i} &= \sum_{i = 0}^{2006} \frac{{2005 \choose i+1}}{{2006 \choose i+2}} - \sum_{i = 0}^{2005} \frac{{2004 \choose i}}{{2005 \choose i+1}} \\\ &= \sum_{i = 0}^{2006} \frac{\frac{1}{i+2} \cdot {2005 \choose i+1}}{{2006 \choose i+2}} - \sum_{i = 0}^{2005} \frac{\frac{1}{i+1} \cdot {2004 \choose i}}{{2005 \choose i+1}} \\\ &= \sum_{i = 0}^{2006} \frac{1}{i+2} - \sum_{i = 0}^{2005} \frac{1}{i+1} \\\ &= 1 - \frac{1}{2007} \\\ &=\frac{2006}{2007}. \end{split}$$

Final Answer: $\boxed{\frac{2006}{2007}}.$ I hope it is correct.
ground_truth:
More generally, suppose $(a_i),$ $(b_i),$ $(c_i)$ represent the entries in rows $n - 1,$ $n,$ $n + 1$ of Pascal's triangle.  Then
\[a_i = \binom{n - 1}{i}, \ b_i = \binom{n}{i}, \ c_i = \binom{n + 1}{i},\]so
\begin{align*}
\frac{a_i}{b_i} &= \frac{\binom{n - 1}{i}}{\binom{n}{i}} \\
&= \frac{\frac{(n - 1)!}{i! (n - i - 1)!}}{\frac{n!}{i! (n - i)!}} \\
&= \frac{(n - 1)! (n - i)!}{n! (n - i - 1)!} \\
&= \frac{n - i}{n} \\
&= 1 - \frac{i}{n}.
\end{align*}Hence,
\begin{align*}
\sum_{i = 0}^{n - 1} \frac{a_i}{b_i} &= \sum_{i = 0}^{n - 1} \left( 1 - \frac{i}{n} \right) \\
&= n - \frac{(n - 1)n/2}{n} \\
&= n - \frac{n - 1}{2} = \frac{n + 1}{2}.
\end{align*}Likewise,
\[\frac{b_i}{c_i} = 1 - \frac{i}{n + 1},\]and
\[\sum_{i = 0}^n \frac{b_i}{c_i} = \frac{n + 2}{2}.\]Hence,
\[\sum_{i = 0}^n \frac{b_i}{c_i} - \sum_{i = 0}^{n - 1} \frac{a_i}{b_i} = \frac{n + 2}{2} - \frac{n + 1}{2} = \boxed{\frac{1}{2}}.\]
